content:
**Entry 1**

I found a pen.

That's the first thing. I should write that down. I found a pen in my pocket and I don't remember putting it there. I found paper too — a notebook, small, spiral-bound, the kind you'd buy at a gas station. The cover is plain. Brown. There's no brand name.

I've been walking for what feels like hours. Maybe longer. There's no way to tell time here. My phone is dead. My watch stopped. The second hand just... stopped. It points at the seven. I keep checking it like it might start again.

The rooms all look the same. Yellow wallpaper — not paint, wallpaper, I can see the seams — with a pattern that's almost floral but not quite. Like someone described flowers to a machine and the machine tried its best. The carpet is that office carpet, the kind with the tiny loops. Brownish. Grayish. Wet.

I tried to find where I came in. I can't. I walked backwards for a while, retracing my steps, but the rooms had changed. Or I had changed. One of us moved when I wasn't looking.

I'm thirsty.

I'm trying not to think about that.

The buzzing is constant. It doesn't get louder or softer. It just *is*. Like it was always there and I'm only now hearing it. Like maybe I've been hearing it my whole life and everything before was the dream.

I need to stay calm. I need to observe. I need to find a pattern.

There has to be a pattern.

**End of Entry 1**

**Entry 2**

I found a room that was different.

Not different enough. Not *exit* different. But the wallpaper had a stain on it — a brown mark, vaguely circular, about the size of my palm. I stood there staring at it for a long time. I touched it. It was dry. Everything else here is damp but this stain was dry and I almost cried because it was *something*. Something distinguishable. Something I could use.

I marked it in my mind. I thought: this is a landmark now. I can navigate from here.

I walked away. Left, left, straight, right. I counted my steps. 47 steps.

Then I found the stain again.

Same wall. Same position. Same dry brown circle.

I had not turned around.

---

I'm sitting now. My legs hurt. The carpet squelches when I shift my weight and I try not to think about what's making it wet. There are no pipes visible. No sprinklers. The ceiling is solid — those foam tiles, the kind with the little holes, the kind that made you think about asbestos in old school buildings.

The fluorescent lights don't flicker. I keep waiting for them to flicker. In movies they always flicker before something bad happens. These don't. They're steady. Reliable. They will never turn off.

I think that's worse.

---

I've started talking to myself. Out loud. Just small things — "okay," "turn here," "watch the corner." My voice sounds wrong. Flat. Like the walls are eating the echo before it can form.

I said my name out loud and I didn't recognize it.

I'm not writing my name here. I don't know why. It feels like if I write it down, something else will read it. Something that shouldn't know.

That's irrational.

I know that's irrational.

---

The hum behind the walls changed pitch. Just for a second. Lower. Then back.

I'm going to keep moving.

**End of Entry 2**

**Entry 3**

I found water.

Not clean water. Not water I would drink. But water — standing in a corner where two walls met, pooled in a depression in the carpet that shouldn't have been there. The carpet dipped down like something heavy had rested there for a long time. The water was maybe an inch deep. Yellowish. Still.

I crouched next to it and looked at my reflection.

I looked away.

I don't want to write about what I saw. Not yet. Maybe not ever. It was my face. It was definitely my face. But the expression was wrong. I was staring down at the water with my mouth closed. The reflection was staring up at me with its mouth open.

Just slightly open. Like it was about to speak.

I stood up fast. Too fast. My vision went gray at the edges and I had to lean against the wall. The wallpaper was damp under my hand. Warm. Body temperature.

I moved on.

---

I've started marking walls with my pen. Small marks — a single line, diagonal, in corners at eye level. I've made seven marks so far. I've passed three of them twice.

The geometry is learning me. That's how it feels. Like it watches how I move, how I think, and it folds itself around my expectations. I expect a long hallway, I get a long hallway. I expect a door, there's a door. But the outcomes never match. The door leads to another room. The hallway ends where it shouldn't.

I tried walking with my eyes closed. Thirty steps. When I opened them I was in a room with no doors.

I stood there for a long time.

Then I turned around and there was a door.

---

The thirst is worse. My tongue feels thick. I keep swallowing nothing. The wet carpet mocks me — all this moisture, all this dampness, and none of it safe. None of it real in the way I need it to be.

I licked my palm. Just to feel something wet.

It tasted like the air here smells. Sweet. Chemical. Wrong.

---

New observation: the ceiling tiles have small holes in them, arranged in a grid pattern. I counted the holes in one tile. 847. I counted again. 846. I counted a third time and stopped at 500 because my eyes were watering and I realized I hadn't blinked in several minutes.

I'm documenting. That's what matters. I'm observing. I'm being systematic.

The hum is still there. It hasn't changed pitch again.

I keep listening for it to change.

---

I found something else in my pocket. A receipt. Faded, crumpled, the ink almost illegible. I could make out a few words: *thank you* and *come again* and a number that might have been a date or a price. 7.47. Or maybe 7/47. Or maybe neither.

I don't remember the purchase. I don't remember the store. But I held that receipt for a long time, pressing it flat against my leg, tracing the ghost of the words with my fingertip.

Proof. Proof that there was a before. That I existed in a place with stores and receipts and transactions.

I put it back in my pocket.

I check for it every few minutes.

It's still there.

For now.

**End of Entry 3**

**Entry 4**

I slept.

I think I slept. I don't remember deciding to. I was walking, and then I was on the floor, and the carpet was pressed against my cheek, and some amount of time had passed. My neck hurts. My right arm is numb from the elbow down — I was lying on it.

The lights were still on. They're always on. But something about waking up under fluorescent lights feels more wrong than falling asleep under them. Sleep is supposed to be dark. Sleep is supposed to be a transition. Here it's just... a gap. A missing piece.

I checked my pen marks. I'm in a section I haven't marked yet.

I don't know if I walked here in my sleep or if the rooms moved while I was unconscious.

---

My handwriting is getting worse. I can see it, comparing this entry to the first one. The letters lean more. The lines aren't straight. My hand shakes now — a small tremor, not constant, but there when I'm not paying attention.

The thirst.

I need to stop thinking about the thirst.

---

I found a chair.

Just one. Metal frame, padded seat, the kind you'd see in a waiting room. It was sitting in the middle of a room, facing a wall. Nothing else. No desk, no table, no other chairs. Just this one, positioned like someone had been sitting in it, looking at the wallpaper.

I sat down.

I don't know why. My legs were tired, yes, but it was more than that. The chair was *there*. It was *for* sitting. The logic of it pulled at me — here is a chair, you are tired, sit down.

I sat and faced the wall.

The wallpaper pattern shifted. Not moved — I don't mean it animated. But the shapes seemed to organize differently the longer I looked. The almost-flowers became almost-faces became almost-flowers again. I watched for what might have been minutes or might have been an hour.

When I stood up, I felt like I'd lost something. Not a physical object. Something else. A thought I'd been holding onto. A resolve.

I'm not sitting in any more chairs.

---

New sound today.

Not the hum. Something else, underneath it. Rhythmic. Regular. Like footsteps, but not quite. More like... tapping. Something tapping against something else, over and over, in a pattern I almost recognize.

I stood still and listened. The sound didn't get closer. It didn't get farther. It maintained its distance perfectly, as if it was moving when I moved, stopping when I stopped.

I walked quickly for a hundred steps. The tapping matched my pace.

I stopped. It stopped.

I took one slow step. One tap.

---

I haven't written about the thing I'm most afraid of.

I'm afraid that I've been here before. That this isn't the first time. That I've walked these halls, written in this notebook, documented these observations, and then... something happened. And I started over. And I'm doing it all again, thinking it's the first time, but it's not.

The notebook has used pages in the back. I found them. Pages with writing — *my* writing — but the words are crossed out. Scribbled over. Obscured.

I can make out fragments:

*don't trust the*

*third door always*

*it knows when you're*

*STOP LOOKING AT THE*

I didn't write these. I don't remember writing these.

But it's my handwriting.

---

The receipt is still in my pocket. I checked.

The receipt is still in my pocket.

**End of Entry 4**

**Entry 5**

I found the third door.

I didn't mean to. I wasn't looking for it — or maybe I was, after reading those scratched-out words. *Third door always.* Always what? I don't know. But I've been counting doors now, counting them compulsively, and when I reached a hallway with three doors in a row on the left side, I stopped.

The first door opened to another room. Yellow walls. Wet carpet. The same.

The second door opened to another room. Identical. Or close enough.

The third door was locked.

I stood in front of it for a long time. The handle was different — older, brass instead of the brushed nickel of the others. Tarnished. When I touched it, it was cold. Everything here is room temperature, body temperature, blood-warm. But this handle was *cold*.

I tried it again. Still locked.

I pressed my ear against the door.

Nothing. No hum. That's what I noticed — the hum stopped at this door. Like the space beyond it was outside the frequency, outside the system. A bubble of silence in the endless buzz.

I knocked.

I don't know why I knocked.

---

Three knocks back.

---

I'm in a different part of the rooms now. I ran. I don't remember deciding to run, but I ran, and the hallways blurred past, and I didn't count my steps or mark the walls or do anything systematic. I just moved.

The tapping sound is gone. The knocking stopped. The hum is back to normal.

I'm sitting against a wall. The wallpaper is peeling here — a corner of it curling away from the wall, revealing something underneath. Not drywall. Something darker. I haven't touched it.

I'm not going to touch it.

---

My pen is running low on ink. I can see it — the lines are getting lighter, scratchier. I don't know how many entries I have left. I don't know how many pages.

I've been thinking about the old entries. The crossed-out ones. If I wrote them before, if there was a version of me that came through here and left warnings, why can't I remember? Why would I cross them out instead of leaving them clear?

Unless I wasn't the one who crossed them out.

Unless something else didn't want me to read them.

---

New observation: some of the ceiling tiles are missing. Not broken — *missing*. Clean rectangular gaps, revealing darkness above. I can't see what's up there. The light doesn't reach. I stood under one of the gaps and looked up and saw nothing. Not blackness like shadow, but nothing like *absence*. Like the concept of vision didn't apply.

I thought I heard breathing.

Slow. Deep. Patient.

I moved on.

---

The receipt in my pocket has changed.

The words are different now. The faded ink has shifted, or I'm reading it wrong, or it was always this way and I'm only now seeing it correctly. It says:

*we miss you*
*come back*
*7:47*

Is that a time?

Is someone waiting for me?

---

I tried to remember my name again. Just now. I closed my eyes and thought about who I was before this place, before the yellow walls and the wet carpet and the endless hum. I thought about hands that might have held mine. Voices that might have called for me. A door I might have walked through without knowing it would close behind me.

I couldn't find it. My name. It's there, I know it's there, but it's behind something. Behind a wall I can't mark. Behind a door I can't open.

Maybe that's what the third door is.

Maybe I'm on the wrong side of myself.

---

The pen is fading. I have to press harder now, dig into the paper.

I'm going back. To the third door. To the cold handle and the silence and the three knocks that answered mine.

Whatever is behind it already knows I'm here.

I might as well know it too.

**End of Entry 5**

**Entry 6**

I didn't go back to the third door.

I want to be clear about that. I intended to. I wrote that I would. I stood up, I oriented myself in the direction I thought I'd come from, and I started walking.

But the rooms wouldn't let me.

That's how it felt. Not that I got lost — I'm always lost here — but that the space itself was redirecting me. Gently. Firmly. Every left turn deposited me into a room I'd seen before, marked with my diagonal line. Every right turn stretched into a hallway that seemed to lengthen as I walked, the far end never getting closer. I walked for what felt like hours. I ended up somewhere new.

Somewhere worse.

---

The carpet is dry here.

I didn't notice at first. I was so focused on walking, on counting, on the mechanical act of movement, that I'd gone a hundred steps before I realized my footsteps sounded different. Harder. No squelch. I stopped and looked down and the carpet was the same brownish-gray, the same tiny loops, but when I pressed my palm against it, nothing. No moisture. No warmth.

I should have been relieved.

I wasn't.

---

The walls are different too. Same yellow, same almost-floral pattern, but the seams don't line up the same way. The wallpaper was applied by different hands here. Or no hands. Or something that understood the concept of wallpaper but not the practice of it. Some strips overlap where they shouldn't. Some stop mid-wall, leaving a gap of bare... not drywall. That darker material. The stuff I saw behind the peeling corner.

I looked at it this time. I didn't touch it, but I looked.

It's not a color. That's the closest I can come to describing it. It's the color of the space above the missing ceiling tiles. The color of closing your eyes in a room with no light and realizing that darkness has texture, has *depth*, has something moving through it that you can almost perceive.

I looked away.

When I looked back, the wallpaper had covered it again.

---

The hum is different here. Higher. Thinner. It doesn't sit behind my eyes anymore — it sits in my teeth. In the roots of my teeth, vibrating at a frequency that makes me want to press my jaw shut and never open it.

I've been clenching. I can feel the ache now, the soreness in the muscles running up to my temples. I try to relax and it works for a few seconds and then I notice the sound again and my jaw locks up.

---

I found another chair.

Not the same one. This one is wooden. Straight-backed. The kind of chair that belongs at a kitchen table, at a dining room, in a *home*. It was sitting in a corner, facing out into the room, and there was something on the seat.

A notebook.

Small. Spiral-bound. Brown cover.

I didn't pick it up.

I stood there looking at it for a long time, my hands shaking, the pen trembling against my own notebook. It was identical. Exactly identical. Same size, same shade of brown, same spiral binding with the same number of loops.

I counted. Seventeen loops on mine. I counted the one on the chair without touching it.

Seventeen.

---

I left. I walked away. I didn't run this time because I didn't trust my legs, didn't trust that I wouldn't fall and stay down, but I walked fast, faster than I should have in a place where every step might take me somewhere I can't come back from.

Behind me — I didn't look, but I heard — behind me, something shifted. The chair. Or something in the chair. The sound of weight redistributing. The sound of someone who had been sitting very still for a very long time, beginning to move.

I didn't look.

I don't want to know if the chair is empty now.

I don't want to know if the notebook is still on the seat, or if something is holding it, or if something is writing in it while I write in mine, documenting me the way I'm documenting this, filling pages with observations about the thing that wanders these halls, the thing that thinks it's alone, the thing that hasn't realized yet that it's the one being watched.

---

The receipt.

I checked the receipt.

I shouldn't have. I knew I shouldn't have. But my hand went to my pocket the way hands do, automatic, thoughtless

**Entry 7**

The receipt is gone.

I've checked seventeen times. Both pockets. The small pocket inside the larger pocket that I forgot existed until I was desperate. The folds of my notebook, in case it slipped between pages. The floor around where I'm sitting.

Gone.

Something took it, or it was never there, or I finally lost the last proof that a world exists outside these walls. I keep patting my pocket. The motion has become automatic — every few seconds, my hand moves, presses against fabric, finds nothing.

I'm trying not to cry.

Crying wastes water.

---

I found something else instead.

In the same pocket where the receipt should have been. A tooth.

Not mine. I checked — tongue against every molar, every incisor, probing for gaps. All present. All accounted for. The tooth in my pocket is small. A molar, I think. Adult-sized but worn down, the enamel smooth in a way that suggests decades of use.

It's warm.

Everything here is warm, I know that, but this is *warm*. Warmer than ambient. Warmer than it should be, sitting in the pocket of someone who hasn't had a warm meal or a warm bed or a warm anything in—

How long have I been here?

I don't know anymore. The entries don't have dates. I didn't think to date them. Why didn't I think to date them?

---

I'm back in the wet section. The carpet squelches again. I should feel relieved — this is familiar, this is the devil I know — but the transition happened wrong. There was no hallway between. No gradual shift. I was in the dry place with the high-pitched hum and the wooden chair and then I blinked and I was here.

I don't remember blinking.

I don't remember my eyes closing.

But they must have, because space doesn't work that way, you can't just *be* somewhere you weren't, unless—

Unless the rules here aren't the rules I know.

I keep forgetting that. I keep applying logic from before, from the receipt-world, the store-world, the world with time and names and exits. This place doesn't care about that logic. This place has its own.

I need to learn the new rules.

I need to survive long enough to learn them.

---

The tapping is back.

Different rhythm now. Faster. More insistent. Not matching my footsteps anymore — it has its own pace, its own purpose. I stopped walking to listen and it kept going. *Tap tap tap. Tap tap tap.* Three beats, then a pause, then three more.

Like knocking.

Like the three knocks that answered me at the third door.

I started walking again. The tapping didn't follow my rhythm, but it got *closer*. I could tell. The acoustics shifted — the sound bouncing off nearer walls, arriving at my ears a fraction sooner than before.

I walked faster.

The tapping walked faster.

---

I turned a corner and found a room full of chairs.

Dozens of them. Maybe a hundred. All different — metal folding chairs, wooden kitchen chairs, office chairs with wheels, plastic stackable chairs from school cafeterias. They were arranged in rows, all facing the same direction, all facing a wall with nothing on it. No window. No door. No stain or mark or peeling corner. Just wall.

An audience waiting for a show that will never start.

I stood in the doorway. I didn't go in. The tapping had stopped the moment I saw the room — cut off mid-beat, leaving a silence that felt heavier than the hum.

One of the chairs in the back row was different from the others.

It was occupied.

---

I couldn't see details. The room was too deep, the light too flat, the figure too still. But there was a shape in that chair. A shape that could have been a person sitting very straight, hands on knees, head facing forward toward the empty wall.

A shape that could have been me.

Same posture I default to when I'm tired. Same slight hunch of shoulders I've noticed in reflections I try not to look at.

I didn't go closer.

I didn't call out.

I backed away from the doorway, one step at a time, keeping my eyes on the room until the wall swallowed the angle and I couldn't see inside anymore.

---

The tapping started again.

Behind me now.

---

I'm running out of

**Entry 7** *(continued)*

I'm running out of room on this page.

I need to stop. Breathe. The pen is shaking so badly I can barely read what I just wrote. I'm going to start a new page and I'm going to be calm and I'm going to document this properly because that's all I have left. The documentation. The observation. The pretense that recording what happens to me gives me some measure of control over it.

---

**Entry 8**

I found water I can drink.

I need to write that first because it's the only good thing and I need to hold onto it. A water cooler — the kind from offices, the blue jug on top, the little paper cups in a dispenser on the side. It was standing in a corner of a room like it had always been there, like someone had wheeled it in for the staff and forgotten about it.

I didn't trust it. I stood there for what felt like an hour, staring at it, waiting for something to be wrong. The jug was full. The water inside was clear. No yellow tint. No film on the surface. When I finally pressed the lever, water came out cold and clean and I almost collapsed.

I drank four cups. Then I made myself stop because I didn't know if my stomach could handle it, didn't know what drinking nothing for however-long would do to my body when I suddenly drank something. I sat on the wet carpet next to the cooler and I waited for the cramps.

They didn't come.

I filled my pockets with the little paper cups, folded flat. I can refill them if I find another cooler. If the cooler is still here when I come back. If anything here stays where I leave it.

---

The figure in the chair room is following me.

I haven't seen it directly since then. But I see evidence. In rooms I've already marked, I find a chair that wasn't there before — just one, positioned near a wall, facing the direction I entered from. Like it arrived moments before I did. Like it was waiting for me.

I've stopped entering rooms with chairs.

This is harder than it sounds. Chairs appear in hallways now. Blocking passages. I have to turn sideways to squeeze past them, and when I do, I feel something. Not a touch — nothing touches me. But a *displacement*. The air shifting in a way that suggests presence. The hum changing frequency for just a moment, as if something else's proximity is interfering with the signal.

I don't look at the chairs when I pass them.

I don't look at what might be sitting in them.

---

New observation: the fluorescent lights have a pattern.

I didn't notice before because I wasn't looking, wasn't thinking, was too busy being terrified to actually *observe*. But there's a rhythm to them. Not the buzzing — the buzzing is constant — but the *flicker*. They do flicker, just not visibly. I had to close my eyes and watch the light through my eyelids, watch the red-orange glow that means *light is here*, and I saw it pulse.

Slow. Regular. About once every three seconds.

Like a heartbeat.

I don't know whose.

---

The tooth is still in my pocket. I keep reaching for it instead of the receipt. My fingers close around it and for a moment I expect the smoothness of paper and instead I get the smoothness of enamel and every time it's a small shock.

I've started talking to it.

Not out loud. Not conversations. Just... acknowledgment. *You're still here. You haven't left me. You're something I can touch and hold and know is real.*

The tooth doesn't respond.

That's reassuring.

---

I found writing on a wall.

Not my writing. Not pen — something darker, something that might have been marker or might have been charcoal or might have been something I don't want to name. The letters were large, uneven, the handwriting of someone whose hands were shaking worse than mine:

**THE EXIT IS BEHIND YOU**
**DON'T TURN AROUND**
**IT ONLY WORKS IF YOU DON'T TURN AROUND**

I stood there reading it three times. Four. Five.

Then I turned around.

Nothing. Just another room, another doorway, another stretch of yellow walls leading to more yellow walls. No exit. No door I hadn't seen before. No break in the pattern.

But here's the thing—

I don't know if there *was* nothing there

**Entry 9**

I don't know if there was nothing there before I turned.

That's what I couldn't finish writing. The thought that stopped my hand. What if the exit *was* behind me, and by turning, I erased it? What if the writing was true — not metaphor, not madness, but *instruction* — and I failed the only test this place has ever given me?

I went back to the wall. The writing was gone.

Not scrubbed away. Not painted over. Just... absent. The wallpaper was smooth and unbroken where the words had been. I touched it. I pressed my palm flat against the almost-flowers and felt the familiar damp warmth and there was no trace. No residue. No indication that anyone had ever written anything.

Maybe I imagined it.

Maybe I'm imagining all of this.

---

The water cooler is gone.

I knew it would be. I knew even as I walked away from it that I was making a mistake, that I should stay, that I should build my life around that one source of clean water and never leave. But I couldn't. The chair had appeared — just one, metal folding, positioned between me and the cooler like a period at the end of a sentence. I couldn't reach the water without passing it.

I still have three paper cups in my pocket. Folded flat. Empty.

I keep taking them out and unfolding them and looking at the inside, at the thin wax coating, at the way the light makes them slightly translucent. Proof. Proof that I drank. Proof that I was, for a moment, someone who had what they needed.

The thirst is coming back.

---

Something new:

I found a window.

Not to outside — there is no outside, I understand that now, *outside* is a concept that doesn't apply — but a window between two rooms. A rectangle of glass set into the yellow wall, clear and clean and utterly out of place. Through it, I could see another room. Same walls. Same carpet. Same lights.

But the room through the window was *dark*.

The lights were off. I could see them — the fluorescent tubes, the same as everywhere — but they weren't lit. The room existed in shadow, in the kind of darkness that doesn't happen here, that *can't* happen here, and I stood at that window for a long time, pressing my face close to the glass, trying to see what lived in a room where the lights had stopped.

Something moved.

In the dark room. Something shifted from one shadow to another, a displacement of blackness, a shape that was somehow darker than the darkness around it. I couldn't make out details. I couldn't even make out size — it might have been as small as a cat or as large as a person or larger, much larger, folded in on itself to fit.

It moved toward the window.

I stepped back. I don't remember deciding to — my legs just *went*, carrying me away, and I didn't stop until I'd turned three corners and couldn't remember which direction the window had been.

The room I'm in now has no windows.

I've checked every wall.

I've checked them twice.

---

The tapping has words now.

I don't know how else to describe it. The rhythm has changed — still three beats, still that pause, but the pattern has become more complex. Longer sequences. Variations in speed and force. And when I listen, really listen, letting the sound wash over me without trying to locate its source...

It sounds like language.

Not English. Not any language I recognize. But *structured*. Syntax. Grammar. Someone — something — is trying to communicate.

I don't want to understand.

I'm afraid that if I listen long enough, I will.

---

I found the third door again.

I wasn't looking for it. I was walking, just walking, no direction, no purpose, just the mechanical act of movement that's become my only constant. And then the hallway narrowed. And the doors appeared — one, two, three, all on the left side. The brass handle, tarnished and cold.

I didn't mean to stop.

I stopped.

The silence was there again. That bubble of nothing where the hum should be. I stood in it and felt my teeth unclench for the first time in what might have been days. The absence of that frequency was like a hand pressed gently over my ears. Like being held.

I didn't knock.

I wanted to. My hand lifted. My knuckles aimed themselves at the wood. But I thought about

**Entry 10**

I thought about what waits on the other side of answered knocks.

That's what stopped me. That's why my hand dropped, why I stepped back, why I'm now sitting in a room three turns away from the third door writing this instead of learning what lives in silence.

The knock I gave before — the three knocks that came back — that was an invitation. I see that now. Not the door inviting me in, but me inviting something *out*. A hello. An acknowledgment. *I know you're there.*

Some doors should stay closed.

Some presences shouldn't be acknowledged.

---

I've been counting my pen strokes. Not words — strokes. The individual lines that make up each letter. It started as something to do, something to focus on, something to keep my mind from sliding into the static that lives at the edges of my thoughts. But now I can't stop.

This sentence: 847 strokes.

That number again. The same as the holes in the ceiling tile. The same as something I've already forgotten, some other count that matched, some other pattern I noticed and lost.

847.

The rooms are full of 847s. I'm sure of it now. If I counted the loops in the carpet, if I counted the almost-flowers in the wallpaper, if I counted the drops of moisture that bead on the walls where they shouldn't — 847. Every time. The same number, repeated, embedded, woven into the fabric of this place like a signature.

I don't know what it means.

I don't know if it means anything.

But I can't stop counting.

---

The tooth in my pocket has a twin now.

I found the second one on the floor — same size, same wear, same impossible warmth. I almost stepped on it. Would have, if it hadn't caught the light in a way that made me look down at exactly the right moment.

I picked it up.

I shouldn't have.

But I picked it up, and now I have two teeth in my pocket where I used to have a receipt, and I keep reaching in and rolling them between my fingers, feeling the smooth enamel, pressing them together until they click.

*Click click click.*

Like the tapping.

Like the knocking.

Like everything here that communicates in threes.

---

I slept again.

This time I remember the dream.

I was in a room — not here, somewhere *before*, somewhere with natural light and colors that weren't yellow. There was a window, a real window, and through it I could see a yard, grass, a tree with leaves that moved in wind I couldn't feel. Someone was talking to me. A voice I knew. A voice I *know*, present tense, because even now I can almost hear it, almost catch the cadence, almost remember—

The voice said my name.

I woke up before I heard it.

I woke up with my mouth already open, already trying to repeat the syllables, but they were gone. Evaporated. Replaced by the hum and the wet carpet and the yellow walls and the fluorescent lights that beat like a heart that isn't mine.

The voice said my name and I almost had it.

I'm going to try to dream again.

I'm going to try to go back.

---

The chairs are closer now.

Not following at a distance anymore — *closer*. When I turn a corner, there's one waiting. When I enter a room, there's one facing me. They're not blocking my path, not exactly, but they're *present* in a way that feels like pressure. Like being watched. Like being *herded*.

I tried moving one. Just to see. I grabbed the back of a folding chair and pulled, expecting resistance, expecting weight.

It was light. It moved easily.

But when I let go, it slid back to its original position. Slowly. Like it was on rails I couldn't see.

I didn't try again.

---

New observation:

The wallpaper pattern isn't random. I finally see it — not everywhere, not in every room, but in some places the almost-flowers arrange themselves into something deliberate. A sequence. If I unfocus my eyes and look at a large section all at once, the shapes form larger shapes. The larger shapes form—

A face.

Not a specific face. Not anyone I recognize. Just the *idea* of a face, the primal pattern that humans are wired to see — two shapes for eyes, a shape for nose, a shape for mouth. The wallpaper watches me. The walls have

**Entry 11**

The walls have faces and I can't unsee them now.

Every room. Every hallway. Once you notice the pattern, it's everywhere — the almost-flowers arranging themselves into almost-eyes, almost-mouths, almost-expressions that shift when you're not looking directly at them. I've started walking with my gaze fixed on the floor. The carpet is safe. The carpet is just carpet.

But I can feel them watching.

Hundreds of faces. Thousands. All turned toward me, tracking my movement through their rooms, their hallways, their territory. I am the foreign body here. I am the thing that doesn't belong, stumbling through a space that was never meant for me, and the walls know it.

They've always known.

---

I found a room with no faces.

I almost cried when I walked in. The wallpaper was different — same yellow, same texture, but the pattern was geometric. Squares within squares within squares, nested infinitely, no curves, no shapes that could become eyes or mouths. I sat down in the middle of the floor and I stayed there for a long time, just breathing, just existing in a space that wasn't looking at me.

There was a chair in the corner.

I didn't notice it at first. My eyes were closed. I was listening to the hum, trying to find the heartbeat rhythm in it, trying to sync my breathing to the pulse of the lights. And then I felt it — that displacement of air, that sense of *presence*, that knowledge that I was no longer alone.

I opened my eyes.

The chair was occupied.

---

I need to describe this carefully. I need to be precise. The documentation matters. If I write it wrong, I'll remember it wrong, and memory is all I have left.

The figure in the chair was human-shaped. Approximately human-sized. It sat with its hands on its knees, its back straight, its head facing forward — the same posture I saw in the chair room, the same posture I recognized as my own. But I could see details now. I was close enough.

It was wearing my clothes.

Not similar clothes. *My* clothes. The same shirt I'm wearing now, same stain on the left cuff where I brushed against a damp wall, same small tear near the collar that I don't remember making. Same pants. Same shoes. Same everything.

Its face was turned away from me. I could only see the back of its head. Hair like mine. The same small patch where the hair grows in a slightly different direction, the cowlick I've never been able to flatten.

I said something.

I don't remember what. A word. A question. Maybe just a sound, a noise forced out of me by the pressure of seeing myself sitting in a chair in a room I thought was safe.

It turned its head.

Not all the way. Not enough to show me its face. Just a few degrees, just enough that I could see the edge of a cheekbone, the beginning of a profile.

And then the lights went out.

---

I'm writing this in darkness.

Not complete darkness — there's a glow coming from somewhere, enough to see the page, enough to make out the shape of my hand moving the pen. But the fluorescent tubes are dead. The hum is gone. For the first time since I arrived here, the lights are *off*.

I can't see the chair.

I can't see if it's still occupied.

I can hear breathing. Slow. Steady. Patient. The same rhythm I noticed through the ceiling tiles, the same rhythm that might be mine if I held my breath and listened to the echo of my own lungs.

I'm not holding my breath.

I'm breathing fast. Too fast. The air down here — wherever *here* is now — tastes different. Older. Like it's been breathed before, cycled through other lungs, exhaled and inhaled and exhaled again until there's nothing left but the memory of oxygen.

The breathing continues.

It's not matching my rhythm.

---

Something touched my shoulder.

Just now. As I wrote that last line. A pressure, light and cold, like a hand made of air, like a suggestion of contact rather than contact itself. I didn't turn around. I couldn't. My body refused — not frozen, not paralyzed, just *unwilling*. Some part of me deeper than thought understood that turning around was not an option.

The touch lifted.

The breathing stopped.

The hum came back — sudden, loud, *relieved*, like the building itself exhaling — and the lights flick

**Entry 12**

The lights flickered back three times before they held.

I counted. I count everything now. Three flickers, then steady. The hum returned in layers — first the low frequency behind my eyes, then the mid-range that sits in my chest, then the high whine that lives in my teeth. Like an orchestra tuning itself. Like the place remembering how to be *itself* again.

The chair was empty.

I checked. I made myself check. I turned my head, degree by degree, like if I moved slowly enough the thing that had been sitting there wouldn't notice. The chair was still in the corner. Metal folding. Same as the others. But empty. The seat showed no impression, no sign that weight had ever pressed against it.

My clothes are the same. I checked that too — same stain on the cuff, same tear near the collar. Nothing changed. Nothing taken. But I feel *lighter*. Not physically. Something else. Like a pocket I didn't know I had has been emptied.

I checked for the teeth.

Still there. Both of them.

I don't know what was taken.

I'm walking again.

The geometric room is behind me now — I think. Direction has become theoretical. I move and the rooms change and I write down what I see and I try not to think about the thing that wore my clothes, that sat in my posture, that turned its head just enough to show me almost-nothing.

It wanted me to see.

That's what I keep coming back to. It could have stayed still. It could have kept its back to me, let me believe I was alone, let me exhaust myself with not-knowing. But it *moved*. It acknowledged me. It said, in the only language this place understands: *I know you're here too*.

I don't know if that was a threat or an introduction.

The carpet is changing.

Not the wetness — that's constant, that's reliable, my shoes squelch with every step the same as always. But the *color*. The brownish-gray is shifting. Room by room, hallway by hallway, the loops are getting darker. More brown than gray. More *stained* than neutral.

I crouched down to look closer.

The carpet fibers are matted. Pressed flat in patterns I almost recognize — here a circle, there an oval, there a shape that might be a handprint if I let myself see it that way. Like things have been lying on this carpet. Like things have been *dragged*.

I stood up too fast. The gray crept into my vision again. I swayed, caught myself on the wall, felt the damp warmth against my palm, felt the almost-face beneath my fingers.

The wallpaper pulsed.

Just once. Just barely. A ripple that ran outward from my hand like I'd dropped a stone in still water.

I pulled back.

The wall was smooth again. Still. Watching.

---

New rule I've learned:

Don't touch the walls for longer than you have to.

I don't know what happens if you do. I don't want to know. But when I touched that wallpaper and felt it *respond*, I understood something that my body knew before my mind caught up. The walls aren't barriers here. They're not architecture. They're *membrane*. They're the skin of something vast and patient, and when I press against them, I'm not leaning on a structure.

I'm touching flesh.

---

The tapping has stopped.

I noticed the absence before I noticed the silence — that space in my awareness where the three-beat rhythm used to live, now empty, now hollow. I've been listening for it. Straining. The hum is loud enough that I should barely hear the tapping anyway, but its absence is *louder*.

What stopped it?

What changed?

---

I found something new in my pocket.

Not a tooth this time. Not a receipt. Something folded — paper, but thicker than the notebook pages. Cardstock. The kind used for business cards or appointment reminders or—

I unfolded it.

A photograph.

Small, square, the kind that comes out of instant cameras. The image is washed out, overexposed, mostly yellow-white with shadows that might be shapes. I tilted it toward the fluorescent light, trying to make sense of the blur.

A room. This room. The same yellow walls, the same carpet, the same angle I'm seeing right now as I sit here writing.

But in the photograph, there's a figure.

Standing

**Entry 13**

Standing where I'm sitting now.

I need to write that. I need to get it out of my head and onto paper where it becomes *record* instead of *thought*. The figure in the photograph is standing exactly where I'm sitting. Same corner. Same angle. Same room.

The figure is facing the camera.

The figure has no face.

Not blurred — not obscured by the overexposure or the wash of yellow-white. *Absent*. A head-shaped space where features should be, smooth like an egg, smooth like the worn-down teeth in my pocket, smooth like something that was never meant to be seen directly.

I'm holding the photograph now. I keep looking at it and then looking at the room and then looking at the photograph again. The walls match. The carpet pattern matches. The specific configuration of ceiling tiles — three missing in a diagonal line — matches.

This photograph was taken here.

This photograph was taken *of* here.

The question I can't stop asking: who held the camera?

---

I've been sitting too long.

I know I have because my legs have gone numb, that pins-and-needles feeling that means blood flow has been compromised, that means I've been still in a way that this place might have noticed. Stillness is dangerous here. I've learned that. The chairs appear when you stop moving. The faces in the walls sharpen when you stay in one spot.

But I can't stop looking at the photograph.

The faceless figure is wearing clothes. Normal clothes — not my clothes, different clothes, a jacket I don't recognize, pants that might be jeans. Human clothes. Human posture. Human everything except the one thing that makes a human *recognizable*.

Someone else was here.

Someone else walked these halls, found this room, stood in this corner. Someone else existed in this yellow space before me. And something — the place itself? the figure in the chair? the thing that took my receipt? — something wanted me to know.

Why?

---

I made myself stand.

The numbness screamed through my legs, nearly dropped me, but I stayed upright. I held the photograph at arm's length and turned in a slow circle, comparing every angle. Same room. Same room. Same room.

Except.

The photograph shows four ceiling tiles missing. I see three.

I looked up.

The fourth tile was there — intact, unbroken, fitted into its grid like it had never been anywhere else. But in the photograph, clearly, unmistakably, there's a gap. A rectangular absence. Darkness where foam-and-fiber should be.

The room has healed.

Or the room has *changed*.

Or the photograph is lying.

I don't know which possibility frightens me more.

---

I'm moving again.

The photograph is in my pocket now, folded back along its original creases, pressed against the teeth like they're all part of the same collection. Evidence. Proof. The things I carry because the alternative is carrying nothing.

The hallways are narrower than before.

I didn't notice at first — I was too focused on walking, on the mechanical rhythm of footsteps, on counting the squelches (1, 2, 3, 4, 5...). But my shoulders are brushing the walls now. Both walls. At the same time. The corridor has contracted around me like a throat swallowing.

I stopped.

I shouldn't have stopped — stillness is dangerous, I *know* stillness is dangerous — but I stopped because the walls were touching me and I couldn't make myself move forward into a space that kept getting smaller.

The walls pressed closer.

Not quickly. Not aggressively. Just... *closer*. The way a hug tightens. The way someone leans in to whisper. The almost-faces on the wallpaper were right there, inches from my own face, and I could see details I'd never noticed before.

The eyes have pupils.

The pupils were dilated.

I ran.

---

The hallway opened up.

It happened all at once — one moment I was squeezing through a gap that couldn't have been more than a foot wide, and the next I was stumbling into a room so large I couldn't see the far walls. The ceiling stretched up and up and up, the fluorescent lights becoming distant stars, the hum becoming something vast and cathedral-like.

I stood in the center and turned in a slow circle and saw nothing.

No chairs. No water coolers. No windows or doors or writing on the walls. Just yellow. Just carpet. Just light an

**Entry 14**

Just light and space and the terrible weight of *openness*.

I've been in cramped corridors so long that I forgot what it feels like to be small. In the narrow hallways, I was the right size — I filled the space, I mattered in relation to the walls. Here, in this cathedral room, I am nothing. A speck. A single character on an infinite page.

I walked for what felt like hours without reaching any wall.

The carpet continues. The ceiling continues. The lights continue. But the walls don't exist — or they exist so far away that they might as well not. I changed direction. I changed again. I walked in what I thought was a straight line, and nothing changed, nothing got closer, nothing marked my progress.

I'm sitting now.

The vastness doesn't care.

---

I've noticed something about my shadow.

In the narrow hallways, I never had one — the fluorescent lights are everywhere, even, sourceless, illuminating from all angles simultaneously. But here, in the open, my shadow has returned. It stretches out behind me, long and sharp-edged, and when I move, it moves wrong.

Delayed.

Just slightly. A fraction of a second. I lift my hand, and my shadow's hand lifts after — not quite in sync, not quite following, more like... *echoing*. Like my shadow is remembering what I did rather than mirroring what I do.

I've been watching it.

I shouldn't watch it.

But I can't stop.

---

The shadow is getting longer.

I haven't moved. I'm sitting in the same spot, writing this entry, and my shadow is stretching. Extending. Reaching out across the carpet toward something I can't see, something beyond the range of my vision, something in the direction I wasn't walking.

It's pointing.

---

I followed it.

I shouldn't have. Every instinct I've developed here told me to stay still, to ignore it, to remember that stillness is dangerous but so is *trust*. But the shadow kept reaching, kept lengthening, and I thought: this is new. This is different. Maybe this is the exit. Maybe something here is trying to help.

I walked in the direction my shadow pointed.

The shadow walked ahead of me.

Still connected to my feet, still anchored to my body, but *ahead* — stretching forward instead of backward, leading instead of following. I followed my own shadow across the cathedral room, watching its edges for signs of change, waiting for it to show me something.

It led me to a door.

---

The door is wrong.

Everything here is wrong, I know that, wrongness is the baseline — but this door is *differently* wrong. It's wooden. Old wood, dark wood, the kind you see in photographs of Victorian houses, the kind that's been polished by generations of hands. It has a brass knocker in the shape of a face.

Not an almost-face. A *face*.

Human. Detailed. Eyes with pupils, nose with nostrils, mouth slightly open like it's about to speak. The brass is tarnished everywhere except the features — the eyes are bright, polished, reflective. When I looked at them, I saw myself looking back.

The knocker is at chest height.

My hand is shaking.

I haven't knocked yet.

---

I'm going to describe the door more carefully because I think it matters.

The wood is warm. Not body-temperature warm — *warm*, genuinely warm, like it's been sitting in sunlight. There is no sunlight here. The edges of the door meet the wall cleanly, no seams, no gaps, like the wall grew around it, like the door was here before the wall existed and the wall simply... accommodated.

There's a keyhole below the handle.

I looked through it.

Darkness. Not the absence-darkness I saw through the window, not the nothing-darkness of the ceiling gaps. *Darkness*. Regular. Normal. The kind of darkness that happens when a room is unlit, when light hasn't reached it yet, when you might flip a switch and make it go away.

I haven't seen normal darkness since I got here.

I didn't realize I missed it.

---

The knocker spoke.

I need to write that down even though my hand is shaking so badly I can barely form letters. The knocker — the brass face with the bright eyes — it *spoke*. Not out loud. Not in a voice I heard with my ears. But something went from its open mouth into my mind, words that

**Entry 15**

Words that weren't words.

That's the closest I can come. The knocker's mouth moved — I saw it move, brass flowing like liquid, reshaping itself — and something transferred. Not sound. Not language. *Understanding*. Direct. Unmediated. Like the meaning bypassed my ears entirely and installed itself in the part of my brain where comprehension lives.

It said:

*You've been here before.*

Not a question. Not an accusation. Statement of fact. Delivered with the certainty of something that has watched me longer than I've been watching myself.

I tried to respond. My mouth opened. Nothing came out — or nothing that mattered, just air and the ghost of a syllable that died before it could become speech. The knocker waited. The bright brass eyes stayed fixed on mine, patient, eternal, unbothered by my inability to answer.

Then it said:

*You'll be here again.*

---

I'm sitting with my back against the warm door.

I couldn't make myself knock. I couldn't make myself walk away. So I compromised — I turned around, I pressed my spine against the old wood, and I slid down until I was sitting on the carpet with my notebook in my lap and my pen in my hand and nothing making sense.

*You've been here before.*

The crossed-out entries. The handwriting that matches mine. The warnings I don't remember writing.

*You'll be here again.*

The loop. The pattern. The geometry that learns me and folds itself around my expectations.

I've been here before.

I'm going to be here again.

This isn't the first notebook. This isn't the first pen. This isn't the first time I've sat against a door I'm too afraid to open, writing observations that will eventually be scribbled over by a version of me I won't remember being.

---

The shadow is behind me again.

I can see it now, stretching out in front of me across the cathedral floor, and it's the right shape this time — human, proportional, moving when I move. It led me to the door and now it's waiting. Patient. Like everything here.

I asked it what happens next.

It didn't answer.

Shadows don't answer.

But asking felt important. Felt like agency. Felt like I was doing something other than being *done to*.

---

The teeth in my pocket are warm.

Warmer than before. Almost hot. I took them out and held them in my palm and they pulsed — I swear they pulsed, a rhythm like a heartbeat, like the lights, like everything here that moves to a frequency I'm only beginning to hear.

Three teeth now.

I don't remember finding the third.

---

I'm going to knock.

Not because I think it's safe. Not because I think the door leads somewhere better. But because the knocker told me something true, and truth is rare here, and maybe the door will tell me more. Maybe the door knows my name. Maybe the door remembers the me I was before, the me I'll be after, the me I'm failing to be right now.

I'm going to knock three times.

Everything here speaks in threes.

---

I knocked.

The sound was wrong — too deep, too resonant, echoing through the cathedral space like the room itself was a bell I'd struck. The knocker's mouth closed. Its eyes dimmed. The brass went cold under my knuckles.

And the door opened.

Not swinging inward. Not pulled from the other side. *Opened* — the wood simply wasn't there anymore, replaced by a threshold, a boundary, a space between where I am and where I'm not.

Beyond the door: a room.

Small. Square. A single chair in the center.

The chair is facing away from me.

The chair is occupied.

---

I can see the back of its head. Hair like mine. Posture like mine. Clothes that might be mine if I could see them clearly. It's sitting very still, hands probably on knees, facing a wall I can't see from this angle.

It's waiting for me.

It's been waiting for me.

I understand now. The loop. The pattern. The thing the knocker told me.

*You've been here before. You'll be here again.*

I walk through the door. I sit in the chair. I become the figure that waits for the next version of me to find this room. And when I do — when the lights go out, when the hum stops, when whatever transition happens *happens* —

**Entry 16**

I didn't walk through the door.

I need to write that first. I need to make it real, make it *record*, because my legs were moving and my body was crossing the threshold and some part of me had already surrendered to the loop, had already accepted the chair and the waiting and the endless becoming — but I stopped.

I stopped.

The figure in the chair didn't move. It sat there, patient, eternal, the back of its head so familiar it made my chest ache. And I stood in the doorway with one foot on each side of the threshold, half in the cathedral, half in the small room, and I *chose*.

I stepped backward.

---

The door closed.

Not slammed — *sealed*. The wood returned, the brass knocker reappeared, the bright eyes opened and fixed on mine with something that might have been surprise. Can brass be surprised? Can ancient things that speak in understanding instead of words be caught off guard?

It said:

*That's new.*

---

I'm running now.

Not away from the door — there is no away, no direction that means anything, no path that leads to *out*. But I'm moving. Fast. My shadow streams behind me, correct now, following instead of leading, and the cathedral floor passes under my feet in an endless scroll of wet carpet and fluorescent light.

I didn't sit in the chair.

I don't know what that means. I don't know if I've broken something or fixed something or simply delayed the inevitable. But for the first time since I woke up here, I feel like I *did* something. Not documented. Not observed. *Acted*.

The teeth in my pocket are cold again.

All three of them.

The cathedral is ending.

I can see walls now — distant, but approaching, yellow and patterned and covered in faces that watch me run. The space is contracting. Not threatening this time, not throat-like, just... returning. Like I stretched it by existing in it too long, and now that I'm leaving, it's snapping back to its original shape.

There's a hallway ahead.

Narrow. Familiar. The same yellow walls and wet carpet and buzzing lights I've been walking through since the beginning.

But different.

The wallpaper pattern is reversed.

---

I noticed it immediately — the almost-flowers spiral the wrong direction, clockwise instead of counter-clockwise, and the faces they form are looking *away* from me instead of toward me. I'm walking through the space backwards. Or the space is backwards and I'm walking through it forward. Or neither, or both, or the distinction doesn't matter.

What matters: I've never been here before.

Not me. Not any version of me. This is new territory. Unwalked. Unwritten.

**EXIT**

---

This is the part I don't understand.

And I'm not moving.

---

*The exit is behind you. Don't turn around.*

Is this the same? If I push this bar, if I walk through this door, will I find what I'm looking for? Or will I find another room, another hallway, another loop — just one that looks like hope?

---

The pen is almost empty.

I pushed the bar.

The kind of cold that belongs to objects that exist outside of body-temperature spaces, outside of the eternal warmth of yellow walls and wet carpet.

The door opened.

Beyond it: nothing I expected.

---

Not another room. Not a hallway. Not the outside world with its grass and trees and sky I've been trying to remember. *Stairs*. A stairwell, concrete, industrial, the kind you find in parking garages or hospital back corridors. Gray walls. Gray steps. A metal railing painted with chipped institutional green.

No yellow.

I stood in the doorway for a long time, just looking at the *gray*. My eyes hurt. Not metaphorically — physically hurt, aching like I'd been staring at the sun, overwhelmed by a color that wasn't yellow. I'd forgotten that gray existed. I'd forgotten that walls could be bare and unpatterned and *silent*.

The faces were gone.

---

I stepped through.

The door closed behind me — I heard it, the click of a latch catching, the finality of a threshold crossed. I turned around to look at it and saw only a gray wall. Seamless. Unbroken. No door. No push bar. No EXIT sign.

I pressed my palm against where it should have been.

Concrete. Cold. Real.

I can't go back.

I don't know if that's good or bad.

The stairwell goes down.

I've been descending for what feels like hours. The flights are identical — twelve steps, a landing, a turn, twelve more steps, another landing. I've counted 847 steps so far.

That number again.

I don't know what's at the bottom. I don't know if there *is* a bottom. But the walls are gray and the air is different — cooler, drier, tasting like concrete dust and old metal — and the hum is gone.

*The hum is gone.*

I didn't realize how much it had become part of me until it stopped. The silence in my teeth. The silence behind my eyes. The silence in the frequency where the backrooms used to live.

I keep catching myself listening for it.

---

I almost miss the wrongness.

Almost.

---

I found a landing with a door.

Different from the exit door — older, wooden, painted the same institutional green as the railing. There's a small window set into it at eye level, wire mesh embedded in the glass. Through it, I can see a hallway.

Linoleum floors, white walls, fluorescent lights that don't pulse, that don't breathe, that just *illuminate*. Doors with numbers on them. A water fountain mounted on the wall. A bulletin board with papers pinned to it, too far away to read.

It looks like a school.

It looks like a hospital.

It looks like every institutional building I've ever been in, unremarkable and functional and *mundane*.

---

I haven't opened the door yet.

I'm sitting on the landing, writing this, trying to understand why I'm hesitating. This is what I wanted. *Out*. Normal. A place where walls are just walls and carpets are just carpets and nothing watches you or learns you or folds itself around your expectations.

But.

The knocker's voice. The understanding it pushed into my mind.

*You've been here before. You'll be here again.*

What if this is part of it? What if the loop includes this — the escape, the stairwell, the door to the normal hallway? What if I walk through and find myself in another waiting room, another chair, another cycle?

What if there's no such thing as out?

Three teeth that I carried through the yellow halls.

Gone.

**Entry 18**

I don't remember finishing that last sentence.

The pen must have slipped. Or I fell asleep again — that gap-sleep, the kind without transition, without the mercy of closing your eyes first. I'm still on the landing. The door is still there, the wire-mesh window still showing me that impossibly normal hallway. But something has changed.

The lights in the hallway are off.

Not broken — I can see the tubes, intact, whole, just... unlit. The hallway beyond the glass is dark now. Normal dark. The kind of dark I saw through the keyhole of the brass-knocker door. The kind of dark that made me homesick for a world where light was something you could *control*.

I pressed my face to the window. Cupped my hands around my eyes to block the stairwell's fluorescence.

Movement.

Something in the dark hallway. Something walking, slow and deliberate, past the doors with numbers on them. I couldn't see details — just the displacement of shadow, the sense of mass moving through space. It passed the water fountain. It passed the bulletin board.

---

I'm writing this from three flights up.

I didn't run. I *retreated* — controlled, quiet, one step at a time, keeping my eyes on that wire-mesh window until the angle swallowed it. The thing on the other side didn't move while I watched. It stood there, facing the door, close enough that it must have been able to see me through the glass.

It didn't try to open the door.

That's what I keep thinking about. The door has a handle on both sides. I could see it — institutional lever-style, the kind designed for easy egress. The thing in the dark hallway could have opened it. Could have come through. Could have followed me up the stairs I'm now climbing.

It chose not to.

Why?

---

The stairwell continues upward.

I don't know why I assumed it only went down. The geometry was descending when I arrived — I entered from above, I walked downward, so *down* became the direction of progress. But the stairs go up too. Same gray walls. Same green railing. Same twelve-step flights turning at identical landings.

I've climbed 412 steps.

My legs burn. My lungs burn. The air is thinner here — or feels thinner, tastes different, like altitude even though I know I can't actually be climbing high enough for altitude to matter.

Unless I can.

Unless the rules here are different too.

---

I found another door.

Same style — green paint, wire-mesh window, lever handle. Through the glass: another hallway. But this one is lit. Bright. Almost *too* bright, the fluorescents cranked to maximum, every surface gleaming white and sterile.

And empty.

Completely, utterly empty. No furniture. No water fountain. No bulletin board. Just walls and floor and ceiling and light, stretching to a vanishing point that might be a corner or might be infinity.

I watched for a long time.

Nothing moved.

Nothing breathed.

---

I'm going to try this one.

I know I said that before — I know I hesitated, I know I wrote about hesitation instead of acting. But the dark hallway taught me something. Waiting doesn't make things safer. Observing doesn't give you control. The only difference between me and the me who sat in that chair, who became the figure that waits, is that I *moved*.

I'm going to keep moving.

---

The handle is warm.

Not body-temperature warm. Not yellow-walls warm. *Warm* like the wooden door with the brass knocker, warm like something that's been waiting in sunlight, warm like welcome.

I don't trust it.

I'm opening it anyway.

---

The hallway smells like hospitals.

Antiseptic. Clean. That particular chemical sharpness that means *someone is trying very hard to kill every germ in this space*. I'm standing just inside the door, letting my eyes adjust to the brightness, letting my lungs learn this new air.

The door closed behind me.

I turned to look.

It's still there. Green paint. Wire mesh. Handle on this side too.

I can go back.

I don't know why that matters so much, but it does. The exit from the backrooms was one-way — the wall sealed behind me, the door erased, the path forward the only path. This door stays.

The light through the window has shifted — later now, the gold deepening toward orange, the shadows in the room stretching longer. I've been watching them move. The shadows. They behave correctly here. They follow the light, lengthen as the sun descends, do exactly what shadows are supposed to do.

I don't trust them.

They made dinner.

I could hear them in the kitchen — the rhythm of cooking, knife against cutting board, oil sizzling in a pan. Normal sounds. I managed three bites.

They didn't push for more.

We sat like that for a long time.

I almost relaxed.

Almost.

---

I counted.

One pulse every three seconds.

I stood up.

"Are you okay?" they asked.
